nodes.text: Symmetry, Integrability and Geometry: Methods and Applications
SIGMA 16 (2020), 031, 17 pages
Permutation-Equivariant Quantum K-Theory X.
Quantum Hirzebruch–Riemann–Roch in Genus 0
Alexander GIVENTAL
Department of Mathemetics, UC Berkeley, CA 94720, USA
E-mail: givental@math.berkeley.edu
URL: https://math.berkeley.edu/~giventh/
Received September 28, 2019, in final form April 13, 2020; Published online April 22, 2020
https://doi.org/10.3842/SIGMA.2020.031
Abstract. We extract genus 0 consequences of the all genera quantum HRR formula proved
in Part IX. This includes re-proving and generalizing the adelic characterization of genus 0
quantum K-theory found in [Givental A., Tonita V., in Symplectic, Poisson, and Noncom-
mutative Geometry, Math. Sci. Res. Inst. Publ., Vol. 62, Cambridge University Press,
New York, 2014, 43–91]. Extending some results of Part VI II, we derive the invariance of
a certain variety (the “big J-function”), constructed from the genus 0 descendant p otential
of permutation-equivariant quantum K-theory, under the action of certain finite difference
operators in Novikov’s variables, apply this to reconstructing the whole variety from one
point on it, and give an explicit description of it in the case of the p oint target space.
Key words: Gromov–Witten invariants; K-theory; adelic characterization
2020 Mathematics Subject Classification: 14N35
To my K-theory teacher on his 80th B-day
1 Adelic characterization
Let FX denote the genus-0 descendant p otential of permutation-equivariant quantum K-theory
on a compact K¨ahler manifold X , or more precisely, its dilaton-shifted version. By definition
(see Part IX)
Here t = (t1, . . . , tk , . . . ) is a sequence of Laurent polynomials in q with vector coefficients in
K := K 0 (X ) ⊗ Λ, v := (1 − q)(1, 1, . . . ) is the dilaton vector, and 1 is the unit in K 0 (X ).
The ground ring Λ, must contain Novikov’s variables Q, and be a λ-algebra, i.e., equipped
with Adams’ op erations Ψm, m = 1, 2, . . . , Ψ1 = id, which act on Novikov’s variables by
Ψm(cid:0)Qd (cid:1) = Qmd. We assume that Ψm with m > 1 increase the descending filtration of Λ
by the powers Λd+ of a certain ideal Λ+ containing all Novikov’s monomials Qd with d ̸= 0.
The correlators ⟨. . .⟩g,l,d are defined in terms of K-theory on the moduli space Xg,n,d of genus-g
degree-d stable maps to X of compact complex nodal curves with n marked points. Let h denote
the automorphism of Xg ,n,d induced by the renumb ering of the n marked p oints with the cycle
structure determined by a partition l = (l1 , . . . , lr , . . . ), where lr stands for the number of cycles
of length r = 1, 2, . . . . The correlator

equals

With the function FX we associate the “big J-function” which to a sequence t = (t1 , t2, . . . ) of
K -valued Laurent p olynomials in q associates the following sequence f = (f1, f2 , . . . ) of K -valued
rational functions1 of q :
fr = (1 − q)1 + tr(q) + (cid:88)l,d,α Qd ϕα(cid:81)s ls ! (cid:28) ϕα1 − qL , tk , . . . ; t2k, . . . (cid:29)d,l+11
Here the cycle structure l + 11 is obtained from l by adding one cycle of length 1, and L
is the line (orbi)bundle on the moduli spaces formed by the cotangent lines to the curve at
the 1st (unpermutted) marked point. Note that on each particular moduli space, due to its
orbifold nature, L is not unipotent, but nevertheless satisfies P (L) = 0, where P is some
Laurent polynomial (with zeroes – in the non-equivariant setting – at some roots of unity).
Since P (cid:0)q−1(cid:1) − P (L) = (1 − qL)Φ(q, L), where Φ is some Laurent polynomial in two variables,
we have 1/(1 − qL) = Φ(q , L)/P (q ). This shows that each correlator in the series is a rational
function of q (with poles at some ro ots of unity), and – obviously from the definition – having
no p ole at q = 0 and vanishing at q = ∞. The part (1 − q)1 + tr (q) is, in the contrary, a Laurent
polynomial in q, i.e., can have no poles except q = 0, ∞.
The range (= image) of the J-function, viewed as a map t (cid:55)→ f (t), is a (formal, infinite
dimensional) subvariety in the space K∞ of sequences f = (f1, f2 , . . . ) of K -valued rational
functions in q allowed to have poles at q = 0, ∞, or at roots of unity. We denote this range
by LX . It can also be viewed as the graph of (the formal germ at (1 − q)(1, 1, . . . ) of ) the map
K∞+ ∋ t (cid:55)→ f − (1 − q )(1, 1, . . . ) ∈ K∞− , where K∞+ consists of sequences of K -valued Laurent
1We remind that by a rational function, Laurent polynomial, etc. in q we mean a Q-series whose co efficients
are such rational functions, Laurent p olynomials, etc.
Quantum Hirzebruch–Riemann–Roch in Genus 0
polynomials, and K ∞− consists of sequences of rational functions having no pole at q = 0 and
vanishing at q = ∞.
Yet another way to describe LX is to consider FX as a family of functions of the first
input t1 depending on t2, t3 , . . . as parameters. Then the map t1 (cid:55)→ f1(t1 , t2, t3 , . . . ) para-
meterizes the graph of the differential dt1 FX for given values of the parameters t2 , t3, . . . , and
fr := f1 (tr , t2r , t3r , . . . ). The sequences f = (f1 , f2 , . . . ) of the differentials lie in the cotangent
bundle T ∗ K∞+ of the subspace K∞+ ⊂ K∞ . The cotangent bundle space is identified with the
whole of K∞ by means of the polarization K ∞ = K∞+ ⊕ K∞− , which is Lagrangian with respect
to the Λ-valued symplectic form
Ω∞ (f , g) = ∞(cid:88)r =1 Ψrr Ω(fr , gr),
Ω(f , g) = −[Resq=0 + Resq =∞](cid:0)f (cid:0)q−1(cid:1), g (q)(cid:1) dq
Here (a, b) := χ(X ; a ⊗ b) = (cid:82)X td(TX ) ch(a) ch(b) is the K-theoretic Poincar´e pairing on K 0 (X ).
By definition, the negative space K∞− of the polarization consists of sequences f = (f1, f2 , . . . )
satisfying fr (∞) = 0, fr (0) ̸= ∞.
Remark 1. Note that the graph of each fr for fixed values of the parameters t2r, t3r , . . . is
a Lagrangian variety in (K, Ω) (where K is the space of K -valued Laurent polynomials in q), and
the whole family of such Lagrangian varieties for, say, r = 1 determines LX . However, a value
of f1, though “knows” its input t1, does not “remember” the values of the parameters t2, t3 , . . . .
One reason to introduce LX parameterized by all the fr is that from a p oint f = (f1, f2 , . . . ) ∈ LX ,
the corresponding argument t = (t1, t2 , . . . ) ∈ K∞+ is reconstructed by pro jection along K∞− . On
the other hand, there is no reason for LX to be Lagrangian in (K∞, Ω∞ ).
We will give an adelic characterization of LX in terms of fake genus-0 K-theoretic GW-
invariants of X . The fake holomorphic Euler characteristic of a bundle V over Xg,n,d is defined
by the right hand side of the Hirzebruch-RR formula:
χfake(Xg ,n,d; V ) := (cid:90) [Xg,n,d ] td(TXg,n,d ) ch(V ),
where [Xg ,n,d] is the virtual fundamental class, and TXg,n,d is the virtual tangent bundle. The
genus-0 descendant potential F fakeX is defined as a function of t(q ) = (cid:80)m≥0 ϕm (q − 1)m by
F fakeX (t) = (cid:88) n,d Qd n! ⟨t(L), . . . , t(L)⟩fake0,n,d ,
where (cid:10)ϕα1 Lm1 , . . . , ϕαn Lmn (cid:11)0,n,d := χfake(cid:0)X0,n,d; ⊗ni=1 ev∗i (ϕαi )Lmii (cid:1).
The graph of the differential dF fakeX is identified with a Lagrangian variety LfakeX ⊂(cid:0)K fake, Ωfake(cid:1).
By K fake we denote the space of K -valued Laurent series in q − 1. It is equipped with the
symplectic form
Ωfake(f, g ) := Resq=1 (cid:0)f (cid:0)q −1(cid:1), g(q)(cid:1) dq q ,
Lagrangian polarization Kfake± , where Kfake+ consists of power series, and Kfake− consists of the
principal parts of the Laurent series, as well as with the dilaton vector (1 − q)1. Explicitly, LfakeX
consists of vector-valued Laurent series in q − 1 of the form
1 − q + t(q ) + (cid:88) α,n,d Qdϕα n! (cid:28) ϕα 1 − qL , t(L), . . . , t(L) (cid:29)fake 0,n+1,d .
Alexander Givental
In fact LfakeX is an overruled Lagrangian cone, i.e., each tangent space T of LfakeX contain (1−q )T ⊂
LfakeX and is tangent to LfakeX everywhere along (1−q)T . The cone LfakeX can be explicitly described
in terms of cohomological GW-theory of X (see [1, 3, 8] or Part IX).
Theorem 1. Let f = (f1 , f2, . . . , fr , . . . ) be a sequence of rational functions of q with values in
K = K0(X ) ⊗ Λ considered as an element of the symplectic loop space (K∞, Ω∞ ). This sequence
represents a point in the range LX ⊂ K∞ of the “big J-function” of permutation-equivariant
quantum K-theory of X if and only if it satisfies the fol lowing criteria:
(i) For each r = 1, 2, . . . , the Laurent series expansion f (1)r of fr (q) near q = 1 lies in the
Lagrangian submanifold LfakeX ⊂ (cid:0)Kfake, Ωfake(cid:1) representing the graph of the differential of
the genus 0 descendant potential F fakeX of fake quantum K-theory of X .
(ii) For each r, and each root of unity ζ ̸= 1, the Laurent series expansion f (ζ)r of fr(cid:0)q 1/m/ζ (cid:1)
near q = 1, where m is the primitive order of ζ , lies in the Lagrangian subspace
△ζ Ψm(cid:0)Tf(1)rm LfakeX (cid:1) ⊗Ψm(Λ) Λ,
where the operator of multiplication △ζ is given by the formula
△ζ := exp (cid:40) (cid:88) k>0 (cid:18) Ψk (T ∗X − 1) k(1 − ζ −k qk /m ) − Ψkm (T ∗X − 1) k (1 − q k m) (cid:19)(cid:41) .
Theorem 1 generalizes several previously known results. Setting tk = 0 for all k > 1 we
obtain the result of [8] which characterizes the version of genus-0 quantum K-theory which does
not involve permutations of the marked points. Setting all tk with k > 1 equal to each other,
we obtain an adelic characterization of permutation-equivariant J-function studied in Part VII
and Part VIII [5, 6].
In fact one can prove Theorem 1 by generalizing the arguments in the genus-0 pap er [8] by the
author and Valentin Tonita. Our goal here is, however, is to derive this genus-0 result from the
all-genera quantum HRR theorem established in Part IX of this series. That all-genera result
is a formula expressing a quantum state (in the Fo ck space of (K∞ , Ω∞)), which represents the
appropriate total descendant p otential of the theory, in terms of its adelic counterpart described
via the “fake” quantum K-theory. What seems p eculiar at the first sight is that Theorem 1
above is not an adelic formula, but merely an adelic characterization of points on LX (in terms
of their localizations at the roots of unity). How can the quasi-classical limit at ℏ = 0 (and
this is how the genus-0 information is supp osed to be extracted from the quantum-mechanical
description of the all-genera data) fail to yield a formula too? The answer to this puzzle lies in the
unusual feature of the quantum-mechanical formalism of the permutation-equivariant quantum
K-theory, where the Adams operations act non-trivially on the Planck constant: Ψr(cid:0)ℏ±1 (cid:1) = ℏ±r .
Consequently, the quasi-classical limit loses its familiar form of a single Lagrangian variety, and
acquires a more intriguing structure.
In Sections 2–4, we give several aforementioned applications of Theorem 1, and postp one its
derivation from the all-genera quantum HRR theorem till the last section.
2 Example: X = pt
In this case, K∞ consists of sequences f = (f1, . . . , fr , . . . ) of scalar (i.e., Λ-valued) rational
functions of q with poles at q = 0, ∞ or roots of unity, and K∞+ consists of sequences t =
(t1 , . . . , tr , . . . ) of scalar Laurent polynomials in q .
Quantum Hirzebruch–Riemann–Roch in Genus 0
Theorem 2. The range Lpt ⊂ K ∞ of the “big J-function” consists of sequences f = (f1 , . . . , fr ,
. . . ) ∈ K∞ of the form
f1 (q) = (1 − q) exp (cid:40)(cid:88)k>0 Ψk (τk )/k(cid:0)1 − q k (cid:1)(cid:41) t1 (cid:0)q, q−1(cid:1) ,
fr(q ) = (1 − q) exp (cid:40)(cid:88)k>0 Ψk(τkr )/k(cid:0)1 − qk (cid:1)(cid:41) tr (cid:0)q , q −1(cid:1) ,
where tk ∈ K+ are scalar Laurent polynomials Λ+ -close to 1, and τk ∈ Λ+ are arbitrary scalar
parameters.
Proof . We derive this by verifying criteria (i), (ii) of Theorem 1.
It is known (see, for instance, [2]) that the Lfakept consists of Laurent series of the form
where t is a power series in q − 1 which is Λ+ -close to 1, and τ ∈ Λ+ is an arbitrary scalar.
First, we expand fr into Laurent series f (1)r in q − 1:
f (1)r = (1 − q)eTr /(1−q) tr(q − 1), where Tr = (cid:88) k>0 Ψk (τkr )/k2,
and tr are some power series in q − 1. We use here that 1/(cid:0)1 − qk (cid:1) = 1/k(1 − q) + O(1). Thus
f (1)r ∈ Lfakept , and criterion (i) is fulfilled.
Note that the tangent space to Lfakept at the p oint f (1)r has the form eTr /(1−q) Kfake+ .
In the case X = pt, the operator △ζ consists in multiplication by an invertible power series
in q − 1. Therefore, for a primitive mth root of unity ζ ,
△ζ Ψm (cid:0)Tf (1)rm Lfakept (cid:1) ⊗Ψm (Λ) Λ = eΨm [Tr m /(1−q)]Kfake+ .
We want to check that this subspace contains the Laurent series expansion f (ζ )r of fr(cid:0)q 1/m/ζ (cid:1)
near q = 1. We have
f (ζ )r = (cid:0)1 − q1/m/ζ(cid:1) exp (cid:40) (cid:88) k>0 Ψk (τkr )/k (cid:0)1 − q k/m/ζ k (cid:1) (cid:41) tr (cid:0)q1/m/ζ, q −1/m ζ (cid:1).
The terms in the exponent which have pole at q = 1 come from the values of k divisible by m.
For k = lm we have
(cid:88) l>0 Ψlm (τlmr) lm(1 − ql) = Ψm (cid:18) Tr m 1 − q (cid:19) + terms regular at q = 1.
Thus, criterion (ii) is also fulfilled.
Thus, the family of sequences f = (f1 , . . . , fr , . . . ) described in Theorem 2 lie in Lpt . Note
that at τ = 0, this family contains the Λ+ -neighborho od of the dilaton vector in K∞+ . At t = 1,
the pro jection of f to K∞+ along K∞− is [f ]+ = (1 − q + τ1, . . . , 1 − q + τr , . . . ). Thus, the tangent
space at the dilaton point to the entire domain of Fpt is covered by our family. It follows now
from the formal implicit function theorem, that the family parameterizes the whole of Lpt. ■
Alexander Givental
3 Dq -symmetries
We generalize here results of [4, 8], and Part VIII about symmetries of genus-0 quantum K-theory
induced by finite-difference operators in Novikov’s variables.
Pick an integer basis p1, . . . , ps in H2 (X ; Q) with respect to which all degrees of holomorphic
curves in X are expressed by vectors d = (d1, . . . , ds ) with non-negative comp onents di. Let Pi
be the line bundle over X whose 1st Chern class is −pi . Let Dq denote the algebra of finite
difference op erators in Novikov’s variables. By definition it consists of non-commutative poly-
nomial expressions formed from multiplication op erators Qi, translation operators qQi∂Qi , and
can have Laurent polynomials in q in the role of coefficients. We make Dq act on the space K
of K -valued rational functions of q so that Qi act naturally as multiplication by Qi ∈ Λ+ , while
the translation op erators act on K-valued functions of Q by Pi q Qi ∂Qi , i.e., by
For convergence purposes we will further assume that our op erators D (cid:0)P qQ∂Q , Q, q (cid:1) have “small
free terms”, i.e., D(1, 0, q ) ∈ Λ+ (cid:2)q , q −1(cid:3).
Theorem 3. Let D = (D1 , . . . , Dk , . . . ) be a sequence of finite difference operators Dk (cid:0)P qQ∂Q ,
Q, q(cid:1). Then the fol lowing transformation on the space K∞ of sequences f = (f1 , . . . , fr, . . . ) of
vector-valued rational function preserves LX :
fr (cid:55)→ exp (cid:40) (cid:88) k>0 Ψk (cid:0)Dkr (cid:0)P q kQ∂Q , Q, q (cid:1)(cid:1)/k(cid:0)1 − qk(cid:1) (cid:41) fr, r = 1, 2, . . . .
Remark 2. Recall that Adams’ operations Ψk act naturally on K 0 (X ), act of functions of q
by Ψk (q) = q k , act through the λ-algebra structure on the coefficient ring Λ, and in partic-
ular by Ψk (cid:0)Qd(cid:1) = Qkd on Novikov’s variables. Consequently, multiplication by Pi hidden in
Ψk(cid:0)D (cid:0)P qQ∂Q , Q, q (cid:1)(cid:1) turns after the application of Ψk into multiplication by P ki . However,
Ψk (cid:0)q Qi ∂Qi Qd (cid:1) = Ψk (cid:0)qdi Qd(cid:1) = qkdi Qkd = q Qi ∂Qi Ψk (cid:0)Qd(cid:1),
i.e., Ψk (cid:0)qQ∂Q(cid:1) = qQ∂Q . Therefore Ψk (cid:0)P q kQ∂Q (cid:1) = (cid:0)P q Q∂Q (cid:1)k . Thus, the operators in the
exp onent act as legitimate finite difference operators in our representation, i.e., as combinations
of multiplications by Qi and twisted translation operators Piq Qi∂Qi .
Proof . Suppose f ∈ LX . Then: (i) expansion f (1)r of fr (q) near q = 1 lie in LfakeX , and (ii) ex-
pansion f (ζ )r of fr(cid:0)q 1/m/ζ (cid:1) near q = 1, where ζ ̸= 1 is a primitive mth root of unity, lie in
△ζ Ψm (cid:0)Tf (1)r m LfakeX (cid:1) ⊗Ψm (Λ) Λ.
It is known (see, for instance, [1, 8], or Section 3 in Part IX), that LfakeX is an overruled
Lagrangian cone in the symplectic loop space Kfake, and that it is obtained by a certain
loop group transformation △ : H → Kfake from the overruled Lagrangian cone LHX of quan-
tum cohomology theory on X . Recall that LHX lies in the appropriate symplectic lo op space
H = H even (X ; Λ((z))), where z = log q , and represents the graph of the differential of the
genus 0 descendant p otential of cohomological GW-theory of X . It follows (see [4]) from the
divisor equations of quantum cohomology theory, that LHX is invariant under the action of oper-
ators f (cid:55)→ eD/z f where D(zQ∂Q − p, Q, z) is any (pseudo) differential operator (with “small free
term”) in Novikov’s variables. Consequently, since the loop group transformation △ does not
depend on Q, the cone LfakeX is similarly invariant under the action of op erators f (cid:55)→ eD/(1−q) f ,
Quantum Hirzebruch–Riemann–Roch in Genus 0
where D((log q )Q∂Q − p, Q, q − 1) is any differential operator.2 The op erator in the exponent
here is required to have at most the 1st order pole at q = 1. Besides, the tangent spaces
Tf LfakeX and the ruling spaces (1 − q)Tf LfakeX ⊂ LfakeX are D-mo dules, i.e., stay invariant under
the operators D , and hence under the operators eD (with no pole at q = 1). In particular, since
P qQ∂Q = e(log q)Q∂Q−p, the invariance prop erties hold true for finite difference operators.
Now let g = (g1, . . . , gr, . . . ) be the result of the transformation described in the theorem and
applied to f . We intend to check that g satisfies the criteria (i), (ii) of Theorem 1. Since 1/(cid:0)1−qk(cid:1)
has the 1st order p ole at q = 1, it follows that g(1)r ∈ LfakeX . Furthermore, according to the
invariance properties described ab ove, the tangent space to LfakeX at f (1)rm is transformed to another
tangent space (at g(1)r m ) determined by the polar part of the operator in the exponent. Therefore
T g (1) rm LfakeX = exp (cid:40) (cid:88) k>0 Ψk(cid:0)Dkrm (cid:0)P q kQ∂Q , Q, q (cid:1)(cid:1)/k2(1 − q) (cid:41) T f (1) rm LfakeX .
On the other hand,

g(ζ )r = exp (cid:40)(cid:88)k>0 Ψk (cid:0)Dkr (cid:0)P (cid:0)q 1/m/ζ (cid:1)kQ∂Q , Q, q1/m /ζ (cid:1)(cid:1)/k(cid:0)1 − qk/m/ζ k(cid:1)(cid:41) fr(cid:0)q 1/m/ζ (cid:1)= exp (cid:110)D(cid:0)P (cid:0)q1/m /ζ (cid:1)Q∂Q , Q, q − 1(cid:1)(cid:111)× exp (cid:40)(cid:88)l>0 Ψl m (cid:0)Dlmr(cid:0)P qlQ∂Q , Q, q(cid:1)(cid:1)/l2 (cid:0)1 − q m (cid:1)(cid:41) f (ζ )r .
The transition from the first to the second line uses a version of the Campbell–Hausdorff formula
which rewrites eA+B/(1−q) as eC eB/(1−q), where by A and B we denote op erators without pole
at q = 1. Since the commutator of [A, B] is divisible by q − 1, the operator C also comes out
without the pole.
Comparing with the formula for Tg(1)r m LfakeX , we find that the factor eB /(1−q) coincides with
Ψm (cid:32) exp (cid:40) (cid:88) k>0 Ψk(cid:0)Dkrm(cid:0)P q kQ∂Q , Q, q(cid:1)(cid:1)/k2(1 − q) (cid:41)(cid:33) .
Given that f (ζ )r ∈ △ζ Ψm (cid:0)Tf (1)r m LfakeX (cid:1) ⊗ Λ, and using the fact that △ζ does not depend on Q, we
conclude, that eB /(1−q)f (ζ )r ∈ △ζ Ψm (cid:0)Tg(1)r m LfakeX (cid:1) ⊗ Λ.
As we have discussed, the tangent space Tg(1) LfakeX is preserved by (differential and hence)
finite difference operators. However, Adams’ op eration Ψm changes the representation by which
such operators act. Namely, Ψm(cid:0)(cid:0)Pi qQi ∂Qi (cid:1)1/m (cid:1) = Pi (cid:0)qQi ∂Qi (cid:1)1/m . Also note that ζ−Qi ∂Qi , ac-
ting on Qd by ζ −di , acts trivially on Ψm (cid:0)Qd(cid:1) = Qmd when ζ is an mth root of unity. Therefore
the operator D (cid:0)P (cid:0)q1/m /ζ (cid:1)Q∂Q , Q, q − 1(cid:1) (nicknamed as C in the Campb ell–Hausdorff formula)
acts in Ψm (cid:0)Kfake(cid:1) as a legitimate pseudo-differential operator in this new representation, and
g(1)rm LfakeX (cid:1). This implies that the same is true for the subspace preserves the subspace Ψm(cid:0)T
△ζ Ψm (cid:0)Tg(1)r m LfakeX (cid:1) ⊗ Λ in K fake , and shows that g(ζ )r = eC eB /(1−q) f (ζ )r lies in this subspace.

5 Derivation of Theorem 1
The higher genus formula for the total descendant potential DX of permutation-equivariant
quantum K-theory of X was obtained in Part IX by generalizing to the higher genus case
the approach from [8], where a recursion relation for the J-function of quantum K-theory was
derived from the virtual Kawasaki-RR formula on mo duli spaces of genus 0 stable maps. Rather
than specializing the same method to the genus-0 case, we intend here to extract the genus-0
information enco ded by the generating function FX from the formula for DX . However, we need
to warn the reader, that such a derivation may in the end provide few advantages over the first,
more direct method.
A. Let us first recall from Part IX those aspects of the adelic formula for DX which are
relevant for our goal of extracting from it the genus-0 information. According to the definition
of DX found in Part IX, the genus 0 descendant potential FX enters the total descendant

mod Λ+ .

The relation between the quantization spaces induced by the symplectic adelic map involves
the change from the standard Lagrangian polarization K∞± (using which the adelic product
⊗M DtwX/ZM is lifted to a function on K∞) to the uniform polarization, in which the negative space

with the restriction of ⟨DX ⟩ to the image of K∞+ = K∞/K∞− in K∞+ under the adelic map.
The whole expression has the structure of Wick’s formula of summation over graphs, where
the factors in ⊗M ⟨D twX/ZM ⟩ represent different types of vertices, and the edge propagators come
from the change of polarization. The latter is equivalent to the application of e⊕∞r=1 ℏr ∇r/2,

of D∞X of the same level r.

the terms with negative powers of ℏ:

Recall that each D twX/ZM has the form of the genus expansion D(t) = e(cid:80)g ℏgFg (t) , where Fg ,
which counts contributions of genus-0 stable maps to the orbifold X/ZM , is homogeneous of
degree 2 − 2g in t after the dilaton shift. Contributions to genus-0 part of log DX come, however,
from mappings of those connected orbicurves to X/ZM whose ramified ZM -cover is rational
(though not necessarily connected). If (cid:98)σi, i = 1, . . . , n, are marked p oints of ramification index
mi = M/ri on a connected orbicurve (cid:98)Σ, then Hurwitz’ formula for the Euler characteristic of
the covering curve Σ gives
For eu(Σ) to be positive, we must have g = 0, all but at most 3 of mi equal to 1, and those 3
(call them a, b, c) satisfy 1/a + 1/b + 1/c > 1. Of course, this singles out the ADE -orbifold
structures on CP 1. However, it is easy to check that in the cyclic group ZM there are no elements
of orders a, b, c whose pro duct is the identity, unless it is Am−1 -case: one of a, b, c equals 1, and
the other 2 are equal to m. In other words, if Σ → CP 1 is a rational ramified ZM -cover, then
base CP 1 carries 2 ramification p oints of the same order m, Σ consists of r = M /m disjoint
copies of CP 1 , and the generator h ∈ ZM acts on Σ by cyclically permuting the r copies in such
a way that hr acts on each of them as the multiplication by a primitive mth ro ot of unity ζ at
one of the ramification points (and hence by ζ −1 at the other).
We can now extract from the logarithm of the adelic product the vertex contribution into
the genus-0 part of log DX . It has the form

Quantum Hirzebruch–Riemann–Roch in Genus 0
D. Using the above conclusion, we now aim to extract terms of weight ℏ−1 from the whole
expression. For this we will observe how all ∇mr (that they carry the weights ℏmr ) intertwine Fr
with Fmr (acting through the parameters t(1)m,r on the former, and through the variables t(ζ )mr on
the latter). We claim that the terms of the total weight ℏ−r are obtained by Wick’s summation
over rooted trees, where the root vertex is represented by Fr , al l other vertices correspond to Fmr
with m > 1, and the edges, connecting vertices of lower level mr with higher level mlr, come
from the propagators ∇mlr .
level 4321
Figure 1. A ro oted tree.
This is a purely combinatorial statement. Orient the edges from lower level to higher (Fig. 1).
For a tree just described, each non-root vertex of level mr comes with the weight ℏ−mr and
a unique entering edge weighted by the inverse factor ℏmr . Therefore the whole ro oted tree
contributes with the weight ℏ−r of the root vertex. Conversely, supp ose that a tree has k + 1 > 1
“roots” (i.e., vertices with no entering edges). Then there are k edges in excess of those entering
non-root vertices and canceling their weights as above. Moreover, since the part of the tree
below any fixed level must remain cycle-free, the weights −ni, n0 ≤ · · · ≤ nk of the roots are
ma jorated by the weights m1 ≤ · · · ≤ mk of the excess edges this way: ni < mi . In effect, due
to the divisibility properties of the weights, 2ni ≤ mi. Therefore n0 + · · · + nk ≤ m1 + · · · + mk ,
and hence the total weight of the tree is non-negative. Finally, adding cycle-generating edges to
a tree (even with one ro ot) makes the weight of the resulting graph non-negative.

follows from Taylor’s formula
